metadata.title: Two-dimensional Amorphous Nanomaterials: Synthesis and Applications

sections.text:

Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials (sheet-like materials with few-atoms thickness and lateral size above 100 nm) have always aroused scientists’ interests since 2004 when Novoselov et al successfully exfoliated graphene from graphite using Scotch tape. It is some unique characters of 2D nanomaterials such as the confinement of electrons in two dimensions in the ultrathin region, strong in-plane covalent bond and atomic thickness, ultra-high specific surface area and exposed atoms that enable 2D nanomaterials to show excellent properties in electrics, catalysis and mechanics. Recently, amorphous materials (varied from crystal materials by atomic arrangement) have demonstrated high performance in mechanics, catalysis and magnetic owing to their unique long-range atomic disorder arrangements. Thus, the 2D amorphous nanomaterials inspire a new path to the study of high performance 2D materials. Herein, we summarize the recent progress in 2D amorphous nanomaterials, whose synthetic methods and potential applications in fields of catalysis, energy storage and mechanics discussed in details. The vital blocking mechanisms for synthesis of 2D amorphous nanomaterials and their performance-structure relationship are focused on. Finally, we conclude the review with our personal insights and provide a critical outlook for the development of 2D amorphous nanomaterials.
Keywords: Two-dimension, Amorphous, Nanomaterials, Synthetic methods, Applications

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
According to morphology, nanomaterials can be divided into different classes as zero dimension (0D), one dimension (1D), two dimension (2D) and three dimension (3D) [1-2]. 2D nanomaterials generally refer to materials with sheet-like morphology, few-atoms thickness and lateral size above 100 nm [3-4]. Since graphene was successfully synthesized by exfoliating from graphite in 2004 [5], 2D nanomaterials have always been a heated research topic [6-7]. Many graphenelike 2D nanomaterials have been investigated, such as
hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) [8-9], transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [10-11], graphitic carbon nitride (gC3N4) [12-13], layered metal oxides [14], layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [15], MXenes [16], noble metals [17-18], metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) [19], covalent−organic frameworks (COFs) [20], polymers [21], black phosphorus (BP) [22], silicene [23], antimonene [24] and perovskites [25- 26]. As a consequence of their unique structure, 2D nanomaterials exhibit exceptional chemical, physical, electronic and surface properties [3,27]. Specially, the unique characters of 2D nanomaterials can be summarized as follows:

1) confinement of electrons in two dimensions in the ultrathin region, which generates the unprecedented electrics [28]; 2) strong in-plane covalent bond, which contributes to 2D nanomaterials’ higher mechanical performance [29]; 3) atomic thickness and large lateral size, which enable 2D nanomaterials to have a ultra-high specific surface area [30]; 4) ultra-high exposed atoms, which generate the untouchable surface state [31].
It is also reasonable to divide materials into two classes as crystal/quasicrystal and amorphous according to their atomic arrangement [32]. Comparing to crystal, the most conspicuous difference is that amorphous material do not possess longrange atomic order [33-34]. Although amorphous materials are commonly used, such as glass, plastic and bio-tissue, they are not explored as thoroughly as the crystal [2]. The past decades have witnesses increasingly numerous researches concentrated on synthesis, structure and properties of amorphous materials [35-37], especially for metallic glass and they reveal some unprecedented properties [38-40], peculiarly in fields of mechanics. For example, amorphous CoTaB alloy exhibited a compressive strength of 6 GPa, much superior to that of the other crystal metals [41]. Traditionally, natural amorphous materials are usually considered as materials that have glass transition temperature, represented by amorphous sulphur, polymer glass and metallic glass [42-44]. Recently, some novel amorphous nanomaterials formed by introducing atomic irregular arrangement factors have been successfully fabricated, showing superior performance in catalysis, energy storage and mechanics [37,45-51]. Among them, 2D amorphous nanomaterials are the stars, as they combine the benefits of both 2D structure and amorphous [52], e. g. 2D amorphous cobalt–vanadium hydr(oxy)oxide unfold a low overpotential of 0.250 V (even lower down to 0.215 V when supported on Au foam) for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [53], which are much more energy-efficient compared to the non-precious metal OER catalysis.
Although a mounting number of reviews concerned about 2D nanomaterials have been published recently [3,18,54-56], almost all of them are focused on 2D crystal materials and their specific properties. None has been thoroughly summarized in the hot fields of 2D amorphous nanomaterials. In particular, it is visible that accumulating outstanding researches about 2D amorphous materials have been reported in the past three years and novel amorphous materials except for metallic glass spring up like mushrooms. Hence, we pay attention to the recent progress in 2D amorphous nanomaterials. Not only do we focus on the synthetic method of 2D amorphous nanomaterials, we emphasize on their unique physical, chemical and electrical properties as well. To begin with, various synthetic methods are introduced with advantages and reaction blocking mechanisms for amorphous. In addition to that, the unique properties of 2D amorphous nanomaterials in photocatalysis, electro-catalysis, energy
storage, and mechanics (owing to their amorphous and 2D structure) as well as the summary of property-structure relationship are described. Finally, we conclude the review with our personal insights and provide a critical outlook for the development of 2D amorphous nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2. Synthetic methods of 2D amorphous nanomaterials
sections.text:

Classical crystal formation mechanism is based on nucleation and growth [58-59], and the atomic ordered arrangement is considered as the stable state (Figure 1a). However, the synthesis process of amorphous nanomaterials is unclear. Recent researches have found that amorphous precursor may be a vital intermediate product for the crystal formation process, especially in biomineralization [57]. They may aggregate first before nucleation to keep the disorder atomic arrangements (Figure 1b). However, amorphous nature still remains unstable, having the tendency to transfer to crystal phase [57]. Thus, interdicting or retarding the transformation from amorphous to crystal is the key to synthesize amorphous materials. Having examined the researches of 2D amorphous materials, we found that introducing some blocking mechanisms (e. g. low temperature [60], rapid reaction [40], competitive coordination/adsorption [61], lattice distortion [62] and so on) into the common 2D crystal materials is an alternative way to fabricate 2D amorphous nanomaterials. Fundamentally, these methods can be categorized into two kinds: top-down and bottom-up. Exfoliation is a typical top-down method, which is efficient but limited to materials which have layered structures in their original bulk compounds. In terms of bottom-up approach, ion exchange, laser deposition, electro-deposition, phase transformation, colloidal chemistry solvothermal method and 2D-templated synthesis are representative, all of which rely on chemical reactions at given experimental conditions. Unlike the top-down method, almost all compounds can be synthesized as 2D structure in principle. sections.heading: 2.1 Exfoliation
sections.text:
Initially investigated, exfoliation is the most widely used method to fabricate 2D nanomaterials, particularly for preparation of 2D crystal nanomaterials [64-65].Based on the external factors, it can be classified as mechanical cleavage, mechanical force-assisted liquid exfoliation, ion intercalation assisted liquid exfoliation, ion exchange-assisted liquid exfoliation, oxidation-assisted liquid exfoliation, and selective etching assisted liquid exfoliation [3]. It should be noticed that exfoliation means stripping 2D nanosheets from their bulk crystal that possess original layer structure (most reported 2D nanomaterials are crystal). Nevertheless, introducing some blocking mechanisms into the exfoliation process, is an alternative way to fabricate 2D amorphous materials.
Wu and co-workers [63]successfully fabricated a series of amorphous metal oxides nanosheets (Cr2O3, ZrO2 and Al2O3) by exfoliation from their hydrouschlorides oroxychlorides (Figure 2a). Although the metal oxides mentioned above do not reveal a layer structure, their corresponding hydrous chlorides oroxychlorides have stratified structures in bulk form. Besides, not only does physical exfoliation occur in the synthetic process to form 2D nanosheets, but chemical reactions (including dehydration and hydrolysis) also proceed continuously to form the metal oxide. Specifically, when the hydrouschlorides or oxychlorides were rapidly heated, dehydration of lattice water and hydrolysis of metal ions would come up, accompanied with a large quantity of gas produced shortly, such as H2O and HCl, generating high pressure. The large amount of gas expanding sharply leads to exfoliation of layered reactants to form metal chlorides or oxychlorides, which can be finally transformed to metal oxide by hydrolysis during the heating. Herein, three heating methods including microwave (Figure 2b), flame (Figure 2e) and muffle furnace (Figure 2h) have been adopted to realize the rapid temperature increasing and forward gas release. All the above three kinds of methods are able to synthesize 2D nanosheets (Figure 2c, 2f and 2i), with relative large area (Figure 2c, 2f and 2i) and thickness down to 2 nm (Figure 2l). The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SEAD) characterizations indicate that all of the three kinds of nanosheets are amorphous (Figure 2d, 2g and 2j). Having throughout examined the synthetic process of the modified exfoliation method, it is rational to draw a conclusion that large amount of gas accompanied with apace hydrolysis may hinder the atomic order arrangement during the formation of metal oxide, generating the amorphous nature. As a comparison, stable temperature increasing at 5 oC/min was also conducted by Wu to afford enough time to the gas release
and hydrolysis. Consequently, the products were in form of thick sheets consist of small crystal particles, which further demonstrated that the formation of 2D amorphous nanosheets rely on rapid gas-release generated layer exfoliation and quick reaction to block the atomic order arrangement. To sum up, this work provides a new path to synthesize 2D amorphous nanomaterials by introducing blocking factors into the traditional 2D crystal nanomaterials synthetic method.
Bringing in laser during the exfoliation process is another effective approach to form amorphous nature. Gong and coworkers synthesized free-standing 2D amorphous carbon nanosheets (CNS) by using laser to exfoliate them from naphthalene [66]. The energy of the laser exerts a profound impact on the formation of amorphous nature. When the laser energy is relatively low (1 J cm-2), the laser can afford the energy needed for exfoliation of the target. However, the energy is not enough for their crystallization. With higher energy (e. g. 5 j cm-2), the 2D crystal nanosheets were able to be produced. Therefore, suitable energy is vital for synthesis 2D amorphous nanomaterials.
Organic molecules can also be used to modify the original bulk materials and generate 2D amorphous nanomaterials through exfoliation. Amorphous iron phosphate dihydrate (FePO4 · 2H2O) nanoplates were exfoliated from the
diethylamine-modified FePO4 · 2H2O particles that were
sourced from recycled steelmaking slag [67]. The absorbed diethylamine generated more gaps between neighbouring layer in the particle and partially destroy the crystal lattice. Subsequently, ultrasonication in low surface tension solvent promoted the exfoliation and lattice distortion to form the final 2D amorphous nanoplates. Similarly, iron phenyl phosphate (FePP) nanosheets were produced by ultrasonication assisted liquid exfoliation, when the phenylphosphate was firstly introduced to react with Fe ions to form the lattice distorted FePP [68].
Compared to the massive 2D crystal nanomaterials obtained from exfoliation, such as h-BN, MoO and MoS, the 2D amorphous nanomaterials exfoliated from their bulk ones are much less reported as the difficulty of lattice distortion during the layer exfoliation even though introducing some blocking mechanisms. Thus, more investigations are needed to broaden the synthesis of 2D amorphous nanomaterials through exfoliation method.

They are commonly utilized to synthesize 2D nanomaterials, especially for those composed with their substrates, such as 2D heterojunction [70]. It is the surface area of the substrate that determines the lateral size of the synthesized layer, and the reaction time controls the thickness. Li and co-workers [71] developed an approach to synthesize 2D amorphous MoSx layer by changing the cations from PbS nanosheets (Figure 3a). As the molybdenum sulfides (MoSx) possess much lower solubility product (Ksp) than that of PbS at room temperature, it is feasible to transform PbS to MoSx via cation exchange. When Mo ions were adsorbed on surface of the PbS nanosheets (morphology of PbS nanosheets can be seen in Figure 3b), Pb ions were substituted by Mo ions as they are easier to participate with S atoms (Figure 3a). With the substitution proceeding, surface exposed Pb was completely replaced by Mo. Meanwhile, an amorphous MoSx thin layer was formed on surface of PbS (Figure 3d and 3e). The ion exchange time determines the thickness of the MoSx layer. In this case, the morphology of all the products

It should be noted that the ion-exchange process was kept at room temperature. In this case, there exists no energy for phase to transform from amorphous to crystal. Another typical example is amorphous Ni–Fe bimetallic hydroxide film coated on surface of nickel foam (NF) supported Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays (denoted as Ni-FeOH@Ni3S2/NF) [72]. The amorphous films were produced by introducing Fe3+ and OH- to the NF supported Ni3S2 nanosheet array (Ni3S2/NF) in aqueous solution, where the ion exchange process occurred on the surface of Ni3S2 nanosheet. It should be noticed that the reaction time is extremely short (5 s), which does not provide enough time to generate the atoms’ ordered arrangement. Consequently, the amorphous films were formed. Similarly, an amorphous CoMoS4 nanosheet array on carbon cloth (CoMoS4 NS/CC) was successfully prepared by hydrothermal anion exchange of a Co(OH)F nanosheet array on a carbon cloth (Co(OH)F NS/CC) in (NH4)2MoS4 solution [73]. Having examined other fabrication of amorphous materials, insufficient energy (low temperature or fast reaction), which can restrict the atoms’ order arrangement, is a prerequisite for producing most of them [60]. Besides, some intermediates during the ion-exchange process, which grow on surface of substrates also show 2D amorphous structure, e. g. GaSeN amorphous layer was produced when N replace the Se in GaSe substrates. The intermediate amorphous GaSeN layer’s activation is required for the subsequent growth of the uniform GaN thin films [74].
Layered double hydroxide (LDH) is an easily obtained crystal nanosheet, when some different ions are introduced to replace the original ions in LDH, a novel nanosheet will be formed and the crystal lattice may be destroyed. Thus the amorphous nature will be generated. For instance, the amorphous CoSx(OH)y nanosheets were produced by selectively etching amphoteric Al and the sulfurization of CoAl-LDH synthesized by a hydrothermal method in one step [75]. CoSx(OH)y nanosheets were amorphous and porous after ion-exchange. Besides, a cation exchange reaction can be conducted to exchange amorphous Ni(OH)2 with Co2+, Mn2+, Cu2+ or Zn2+ to obtain a series of amorphous bimetal nanosheets (e. g. Ni-Co, Ni-Mn, Ni-Cu and Ni-Zn hydroxides) [76].

When the ionized elements impact the substrates, they will condense to form layers. However, the energy is not enough to promote the atoms’ order arrangement at low temperature. As a result, the amorphous nature can be reserved.
Voevodin and co-workers successfully synthesized ultrathin amorphous boron nitride (BN) on surface of various substrates through pulsed laser deposition (PLD) [78]. They used a 248 nm KrF pulsed UV laser to strike a rotating boron nitride target (Figure 4a). The nonequilibrium was taken shape by localized heating of the target surface. With the laser beam rapidly vaporizing boron and nitrogen species, a high energy plasma is formed, which is mainly consist of ionized boron (B+), ionized nitrogen (N+), neutral excited nitrogen (N*), along with a relatively smaller presence of molecular species including N2, N2+, and BN. These species reached the substrate location forming the amorphous layer (Figure 4a). The arrival time, concentrations, plasma reactions, and surface growth uniformity could be tuned by adjusting the laser power density to optimize the amorphous BN layer. The laser deposition process here was kept under 200 oC, which can not provide enough energy for atoms’ ordered arrangement, so that the amorphous nature was formed. In addition, the PLD method were demonstrated to be universal. That is to say without changing any of the deposition parameters, the ultrathin amorphous BN layers could be produced on various substrates including flexible polydimethylsiloxane,
amorphous silicon dioxide, crystalline Al2O3, other 2D materials covering graphene, 2D MoS2, conducting metals and metal foils (Figure 4b). The presented BN layers exhibit a thickness ranging 1–5 nm, which can be further accurately controlled by tuning the pulses numbers (Figure 4c). The more pulses, the more BN’s deposition will be generated so that BN layers will be thicker. Recently, Voevodin and co-workers successfully synthesized amorphous BN layer on surface of novel semiconductor of few-layer 2H-MoTe2, which further verified the generality of the PLD method [80].
Besides, 2D amorphous black phosphorus (BP) nanomaterials are usually produced by laser-deposition owing to their high thermo-dynamical stability [81-83]. For instance, the wafer-scale amorphous BP ultrathin films deposited on SiO2 substrates with tunable direct band gap can be made at the temperature as low as 150 °C by conventional pulsed laser deposition (PLD) owing to the focus energy provided by the laser [81], which is in contrast with extreme conditions of high temperature and high pressure for the preparation of BP bulk. Thanks to the relative low reaction temperature, the BP films can remain amorphous. BP films on other substrates such as Si were also synthesized by the similar laser-deposition approach [83].
Another typical instance is the synthesis of amorphous NiO nanosheets by laser ablating bulk crystalline NiO powders in water and methanol solution [52]. Distinguished from the traditional laser deposition, the ablation and reproduction process both occur in liquid instead of separated solid substrates. sections.heading: 2.4 Electro-deposition
sections.text:
Electro-deposition is a common primitive method for synthesis of amorphous nanomaterials, which normally use continuous current or constant voltage to deposit target materials on the surface of electrodes or other conductive substrates in special electrolytes [86-87]. Abundant electrons concentrated in the electrodes generate rapid reaction in order that the amorphous nature is formed owing to not sufficient time for the atoms’ order arrangement.

Jin and co-workers [88] developed an approach for amorphous cobalt–iron hydroxide (CoFe-H) nanosheets by electro-deposited them on graphite disks at a constant potential of −1.42 V versus Hg/Hg2SO4 in a three-electrode
electrochemical cell, using a solution containing Co(NO3)2 and Fe(NO3)3 (Figure 5a). The CoFe-H nanosheets assembled to arrays on the graphite disks (Figure 5b), showing a thickness of 20-30 nm and lateral size of 700 nm (Figure 5c). The amorphous nature of CoFe-H nanosheets were demonstrated by HRTEM and FFT (Figure 5d and 5e). Throughout the cathodic reduction of NO3−, the electrodeposition proceeded, slowly generating hydroxide at the graphite surface, which increase the solution pH that promote bimetallic hydroxide precipitation. The nanosheet structure was formed through the host (Co2+, Fe3+) – guest (OH−) repulsive intercalation induced by the cathodic generation of hydroxide. The rapid electrons transformation were capable to distort the lattice structure of the products, which produced the amorphous state of the CoFe-H nanosheets.
Another typical example is the synthesis of 2D amorphous nickel-cobalt hydroxide (NiCo LDH) nanosheets by electrophoretic deposition [89]. The triumphant growth of NiCo LDH can be attributed to the intrinsic properties of Ni2+ and Co2+. The amorphous NiCo LDH nanosheets were deposited on the carbon fiber paper (CFP) and assembled to arrays simultaneously. High value of viscosity of electrolyte generated the high interfacial energy in the process of crystal growth and only amorphous structure can be formed. Recently, many other amorphous hydroxide nanosheets deposited on various substrates have been successfully synthesized, such as NiFe(oxy)hydroxide on exfoliated graphite foil (NiFe@EG) [90], cobalt-nickel hydroxide on Ni foam (CoNi@NF) [91], nickel–iron hydroxide on Ni foam (NiFe@NF) [92], Ni(OH)2 on graphite [48], Co(OH)2 on graphite [93] or TiO2 mesh [94], which demonstrate the advantages and generality of electro-deposition in synthesis of 2D amorphous nanomaterials, especially for those materials coated on substrates.

sections.heading: 2.5 Phase transformation
sections.text:
Having examined the development of 2D nanomaterials, we found that numerous synthetic methods for 2D crystal nanomaterials have been successfully developed and well studied [3,55]. Based on this, destroying the atomic arrangements of 2D crystal nanomaterials (phase transformation) without affecting their 2D morphology is another promising mechanism to synthesize 2D amorphous nanomaterials.
It is possible to achieve the phase transformation from crystal to amorphous when electrons or ions circularly implant and come out of the crystal lattice, (typical behaviors of charge and discharge in battery [95-96] and electro-catalysis [97- 98]), which tend to generate the collapse of crystal lattice and form the amorphous materials. Choi and co-workers [96] synthesized Si nanosheets with a thickness of sub-5 nm and lateral size of several micrometers through chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process. The prepared Si nanosheets were crystal. Intriguingly, after lithiation process when they were used as the electrodes in Li-ion battery, the crystal Si nanosheets would transfer to amorphous and the 2D nanosheets morphology could be kept. Similarly, the crystal CoSeO3·H2O (M-CSO) nanosheet with metastable, layered structure obtained by exfoliation method can also be converted into amorphous phase at the beginning of the first Li+ discharge cycling as the corner-sharing [CoO6] octahedra in M-CSO can easily twist against each other and lose the long-range order [100]. What’s more, the electrons generated by the e-beam irradiation can also lead the crystal M-CSO convert to amorphous phase. However, it is obliged to notice that the phase transformation from crystal to amorphous is not stable. Put it another way, some amorphous nanosheets can be reverted to crystal after dilithiation [96]. Therefore, the mechanism is supposed to be further studied on how to stabilize the 2D amorphous nanomaterials synthesized by ions or electrons in and out.
Besides electrons or ions, some molecules which circularly implant and come out of the crystal lattice in unique condition may also generate the crystal-to-amorphous phase transformation [50,99]. The ligand N, N’, N’’tris(carboxymethyl)-1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxamide based MOFs (Mn-MOFs, Ni-MOFs and Co-MOFs) composed of 2D non-interpenetrating double anionic layers can convert to
amorphous when the coordinated water was lost during heating [101]. Furthermore, supercritical CO2 have been confirmed efficiency in lattice distortion engineering [102], e. g. heterostructures of WS2/WO3·H2O from WS2 nanosheets [103] and MO3-x from MO3 [104], which is good at promoting the materials’ transformation from crystal to amorphous. Specifically, they prepared MoS2 nanosheets with few layer atomic thickness. The exfoliation from their bulk crystal was a primary step. Then oxygen was incorporated to replace the sulfur atoms in an annealing process (Figure 6a). During the reaction process from MoS to MoO, ordered lattice structure was partially destroyed, while the formed MoO3 still remained crystal phase (coexistence of metastable h-MoO3 and stable α-MoO3) in a limited region (Figure 6a). Finally, supercritical CO2 (sc-CO2) was adopted to treat the samples to accomplish the phase transformation from crystal to amorphous. The vivace sc-CO2 molecules can easily go in and out of the crystal lattice so that the lattice would be distorted and the amorphous nature was formed (Figure 6b). Besides, it’s able for the sc-CO2 molecules to be absorbed on the formed amorphous MoO3 to stabilize them (Figure 6b). The sc-CO2 treatment is an essential process for the formation of amorphous nanosheets. sections.heading: 2.6 Chemical precipitation
sections.text:
Chemical precipitation is traditionally used to synthesize nanomaterials by utilizing the reaction of various ions according to their different solubility [106-108]. A sizable proportion of 2D crystal nanomaterials such as Gd2O3, Ho2O3, and Y2O3 have been successfully synthesized by tuning the experimental condition [109]. Unlike the traditional precipitation method (by simply adding different reactants into the solution for their precipitation), some other agents which could distort the atoms’ arrangement to guarantee the amorphous are necessary.
Small organic molecules such as ethylene glycol (EG) and alcohol have been testified to be capable to serve as the atomic distorted angents to form amorphous materials [105,110]. Pan and co-workers [105] precipitated several soluble reactants including FeSO4 · 7H2O, H3PO4, and LiOH ·H2O at room
temperature to form the cotton-like precursor iron phosphate nanosheets (Figure 7a). Large amount of EG was absorbed by the precursor when EG was mixed in the initial solution. The absorption was proved by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The absorbed EG may distort the adjacent coordination of Fe2+ and PO43- so that the precursor turned into amorphous. Although the precursor would become crystal during the nanosheets exfoliation formation process, the absorbed EG and following alcohol washing would transfer some Fe (2) oxidize to Fe (3) and the oxidation process would continuously destroy the order lattice structure, making the iron phosphate resume to amorphous. Moreover, organic long-chain polymer is another optional additive to form the amorphous materials. Wang and co-workers [111] successfully fabricated 2D amorphous Sb2S3 nanosheets by precipitating Sb3+ with sulfur, which was accompanied with oleylamine (OLA) and n-dodecylamine (DA) as soft templates. On one hand, the organic soft templates guide Sb2S3 to grow along them. On the other hand, they make a difference to the atoms’ arrangements owing to the strong absorption.
Recently, Guo and co-workers [53] provided a new path to distort the atom arrangement during the precipitation. They synthesized a cobalt–vanadium bimetal hydr(oxy)oxide (CoV-UAH) 2D amorphous nanosheets (Figure 7b-7e) with a thickness of approximately 0.7 nm (Figure 7f and Figure 7g). The noteworthy differences from other metal hydr(oxy)oxides are that CoV-UAH were bimetal instead of monometal. Structure analysis revealed the coordination of V in the compounds is [VO4], which strongly distort the the adjacent coordination of Co and O to generate lattice mismatch,
accounting for the formation of an overall amorphous structure. As a comparison, the monometal hydr(oxy)oxide Co(OH)2 were synthesized and exhibited a crystal phase (Figure 7h and 7i). Besides, existence of V species never fail to induce a large number of O–H and V–O groups, making the intercalation of water molecules and/or ions into the metal hydr(oxy)oxide layers easier. Thus, it imped the packing of layers along the c-axial direction to produce a thicker structure. As this approach is not based on the unique characters of the elements, it is likely to fabricate other similar 2D amorphous nanosheets by changing elements, so that bi- or multicompounds may be an efficient way to synthesize various 2D amorphous nanomaterials. Furthermore, the amorphous nickel borate (NiBxOy) nanosheets were fabricated through a facile one-step co-precipitation method (precipitation of NiCl2·6H2O
and NaB4O7·10H2O), during which the room temperature and
short reaction time are not providing enough energy for atoms’ ordered arrangement, which is the key to form the amorphous nature [112].

sections.heading: 2.7 Hydro/Solvo-thermal method
sections.text:
The hydro/solvothermal synthetic method is a typical wetchemical synthesis strategy: using water or organic solvent as the reaction medium in a sealed vessel, where the reaction temperature is higher than the boiling point of the solvent [113]. The up-boiling temperature generate a high pressure in the sealed vessel which predominantly accumulate the reaction [114-115]. Although the morphology of products generated by hydro/solvo-thermal method are well controlled, most of them are well-crystalline due to the abundant energy provided by the high temperature and pressure, profiting the atomic ordered arrangement [113]. As a result, there should exist some external additives which are able to prevent the atoms from arrangement, stabilizing the amorphous state.
Dong and co-workers [116] prepared free-standing 2D amorphous Co3(PO4)2 nanosheets by hydro/solvo-thermal method. They produced a hodgepodge of oleylamine (OM), octadecene (ODE) and water, where oleylamine (OM) and the immiscible interface between water and organic layer possessed a conducive impact for formation of amorphous nanosheets (Figure 8a). The 2D amorphous Co3(PO4)2 nanosheet have a lateral size of 500 nm and thickness of 2.1 nm (Figure 8a and 8c). The amorphous nature can be demonstrated by HRTEM, SAED (Figure 8b) and XRD (Figure 8d) and the constituent of Co, P, O can be observed by EDS maps (Figure 8e). As shown in Figure 8a, OM and metal ions (Co2+) formed an OM-Co precursor in the hydrophobic phase. With the heating time increasing, OM-Co and the phosphate group started to precipitate so that the amorphous nuclues were formed, and the nucleus tended to be nanoplatelike as guidance of the immiscible phase. Excessively absorbed OM hindered the atoms arrangement, decreasing the nanoplates’ surface energy to stabilize them. After that,

sections.heading: 2.8 2D-Templated Synthesis
sections.text:
2D-templated synthesis signifies utilizing the easy obtained surface-obvious materials as templates to conduct the growth of 2D nanostructures, especially for materials whose growth tendency is not 2D [122-123]. The past decades have witnessed the templated synthesis of various 2D nanomaterials [3,124-125]. For instance, Zhang and coworkers [126] fabricated Au square nanosheet with lateral size of 200 and 500 nm and thickness of 2.4 nm by using GO as templates. Virtually, it is unlikely to achieve the synthesis by non-templated method. Nevertheless, most previously reported 2D nanomaterials obtained from 2D-templated synthesis are crystal, and controlling the experimental condition to limit the growth of crystal is an alternative way for synthesis of amorphous nanomaterials.
Guo and co-workers [127] developed a general strategy for synthesis of various ultrathin 2D metal oxide (MO) nanosheets, including MgO, ZrO2, Al2O3, TiO2, SnO2 and Sb2O5, by using GO as templates (Figure 9a). All of them show well nanosheet-like morphology (Figure 9b) with a lateral size of several micrometers and a thickness of 2.1-4.7 nm (approximately equal to several monomolecular layers).

From what is discussed above, we draw a conclusion that most of them are based on the classical 2D crystal nanomaterials synthetic methods which are modified by introducing some blocking mechanisms, summarized in Table 1. The blocking mechanisms could be classified into four categories: to begin with, reducing the reaction temperature, which does not provide enough energy to afford the atoms’ order arrangement so that amorphous materials are produced. Secondly, rapid reaction, in condition of which atoms do not have enough time to finish the atoms’ order arrangement before reaction end, contributing to the long-term disorder atom arrangement. Moreover, competitive coordination/adsorption, which could restrict the reaction or coordination to their adjacent reactants and distort the lattice in result. The final one can be described as lattice destroyed agents such as electrons, ions, molecules and so on, which can frequently move in and out of the crystal lattice to destroy or distort them and help complete the transformation from crystal to amorphous. The four blocking mechanisms are not independent, more than one can be synergistically adopted to promote the synthesis of well-grown 2D amorphous nanomaterials. We believe that under direction of the 2D structure growth and blocking mechanisms, it is likely that more synthetic methods will be developed and more unique 2D amorphous nanomaterials will blossom in the near future.

sections.heading: 3. Applications
sections.text:
Long-range atomic disorder is the most representative structural character of amorphous materials, which generates some diverse unique properties, summarized as: 1) amorphous materials have more defects and reactive sites [133]; 2) amorphous materials exhibit unique surface chemical state [134]; 3) amorphous materials provide advanced electrons/ions transport path [135]. These particular structures and properties are capable to greatly optimize the amorphous materials’ performance in catalysis, energy storage, energy transformation and mechanics [2]. For instance, amorphous manganese oxide unfold better catalysis performance in reaction of isopropanol to propyl alcohol, with high conversion rate and selectivity [136]. When amorphous FeP2 nanoparticles synthesized by Stevenson were selected as the
electrodes, Li-ion batteries revealed an excellent capacity of 1258 mAh g-1 with high stability [137]. Fe based amorphous alloy show a fracture strength of 3.6 GPa, almost 5 times higher than that of crystal steel [138]. 2D nanomaterials also exhibit exceptional chemical, physical, electronic and surface properties owing to their unique structure [3,27], such as confinement of electrons in two dimensions within the ultrathin region, strong in-plane covalent bond, atomic thickness and large lateral size and ultra-high exposed atoms [28-31].
Benefiting from both the amorphous nature and the ultrathin 2D structure, the 2D amorphous nanomaterials possess some unique properties, which are briefly summarized as: 1) Abundant defects. Because of the randomness of atoms in amorphous materials, defects trend to occur [52]. Besides, the large lateral size and ultra-high exposed atoms endow 2D amorphous nanomaterials with high specific surface area provide more exposed surface to form defects [3]. More defects generated by both amorphous nature and 2D structure mean more reactive sites for catalysis reaction. 2) Active electronic state. The atoms’ disorder arrangement may disturb the intrinsic chemical bonds and coordination [53] as well as more exposed atoms provided by 2D structure [31] jointly promote the activity of electrons. 3) Fast transportation of ions/electrons. Amorphous could provide additional channels and paths [81,121] and the atomic thickness of 2D nanomaterials can decrease the transportation length [52], both of which contribute to the fast transportation of ions/electrons. 4) Excellent mechanical properties. Lacking grain boundary and dislocation endows amorphous nanomaterials with a theoretical value-closed strength and hardness [32] as well as the strong in-plane covalent bond further increase difficulty of fracture along the 2D direction [29]. The excellent properties of 2D amorphous nanomaterials generated by the synergistic effect of amorphous nature and 2D structure endow them with widely portential applications. In this chapter, the applications of 2D amorphous nanomaterials including photocatalysis, electro-catalysis, energy storage, mechanics and so forth will be described in details. Their exceptional performance and the relationship between their performance and 2D amorphous structure are to be focused on.

sections.heading: 3.2 Electrocatalysis
sections.text:
Characters of 2D amorphous nanomaterials such as convenient electrons transfer and abundant active sites endow them promising applications in electrocatalysis.
Electrocatalysis processes are commonly classified as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [55]. The past decades have seen lots of efforts made [151-153] to explore low over potential, earth-abundant and inexpensive catalysts to replace the costful and scanty Pt for HER and ORR, IrO2 and RuO2 for OER respectively. Among them, some 2D amorphous nanomaterials possess the marvelous performance in reducing the over potential or promoting the efficiency.
HER reaction involves the process, when protons from the solution are combined with the electrons at the electrode to form hydrogen gas [55]. 2D amorphous nanomaterials provide numerous active sites for absorption of protons, reducing the distance for electrons’ transfer, which is appropriate to the HER process. Wang and co-workers [154] reported a facile method to synthesize ultrathin, amorphous, porous, oxygen and defect-enriched NiCoFe phosphate nanosheets (NSs), which afforded a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of only −231 mV. It is evident that the microporous confinement in a 2D orientation can reduce the ion transport resistance during electrochemical processes, and defect-enriched structure with amorphous nature provided tremendous electrochemically active surface area. Molybdenum sulfides are very attractive noble-metal-free electrocatalysts in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) of water [155]. Recently, amorphous MoSx nanosheets have been observed to exhibit significantly higher HER activity than the crystal ones. A MoS2 based 2D nanocompostie consists of 1T phase MeS2 and amorphous MoSx was synthesized by Kim and co-workers modification [130]. The 2D nanocomposites showed an onset potential and Tafel slope of 114mV and 45.1mV dec-1 (which is lower than the crystal MoS2 nanosheets) as well as stable catalytic properties for HER after the 1000-cyclic test, owing to both additional active sulfur sites for the reaction and restriction of the restacking of the 2D nanosheets (which is provided by the 2D amorphous structure). The crystal and amorphous combination system can be extended. A MoC2/amorphous C nanosheet hybrid was synthesized and subsequently assembled to 3D porous scaffold [156]. the optimized Mo2C/C hybrid catalyst demonstrates an excellent HER performance in both acidic and alkaline conditions with small Tafel slopes of 56 and 48 mV dec−1 respectively, indicating relatively high efficiency. Besides, some amorphous ternary compounds such as CoMoS4 [73] and C-B-P [157] with nanosheets morphology also show exceptional performance in decreasing the overpotential of HER.
OER is the oxidative half reaction in water splitting to release O2 [55]. The OER process is kinetically sluggish, accounting for large kinetic overpotential loss [158]. Thus they are always in lack of high efficient catalysts to expedite the reaction. Compared to the globally scarce IrO2 and RuO2,

The high linear slopes (75.87 mF cm-2) of the charging current density differences against scan rate of the CoV-UAH (Figure11b) implied that CoV-UAH should possess an excessively larger electrochemically active surface area and higher density of catalytically active sites. Insitu X-ray absorption spectral characterization (Figure 11c11f) was conducted here to clarify the underlying mechanism for the OER catalytic activity. During the OER process, it was likely that the Co2+ species in CoV-UAH would oxidize into high valence cobalt species (Figure 11c and 11d) and V ion with lower valence state may appear (Figure 11e and 11f), which accounted for their OER catalytic performance. The ultrathin 2D amorphous structure certainly has a unique advantage, as it offers large solid–liquid interfacial area, structural flexibility and ample defects (e.g. distorted [CoO6-x] octahedron), which are conducive to the ion transport and nucleation in phase transition. Tafel slope of CoFe-H was down to 28 mV dec-1, which lagged far behind that of the benchmark IrO2 and achieve the world record, verifying that the reaction kinetics for amorphous CoFe-H nanosheets were favorable. Recently, some novel 2D amorphous metal hydroxide nanosheets have been synthesized such as Ni-Fe@EG [90], Co-Ni@NF [91], NiFe@NF [92], Ni(OH)2 on Fe2O3 films [121] all of which show low overpotential in OER, particularly the initial overpotential of Ni-Fe@NF was down to 0.2 V [92]. 2D amorphous FePO4 nanosheets in-situ grown on Ni forms (NF) also showed excellent OER catalytic performance [118], with a small overpotential of 218 mV to afford 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 42 mV dec-1. Entertainingly, the amorphous nanosheets exhibited both high performance in OER and HER, indicating the advantages of the 2D amorphous structure.
ORR is the key process in fuel cells and metal-air batteries. There were mainly two ways to achieve the ORR process, one is the 4-electron reduction of oxygen to H2O (in acid electrolytes) or OH− (in base electrolytes), the other is the 2- electron reduction of oxygen to H2O2 (in acid electrolytes) or HO2− (in base electrolytes) as intermediates [159-160]. 2D amorphous nanomaterials are never fail to be used as substrates composited with some metals to enhance their ORR catalytic performance by providing numerous active sites. For instance, Rh nanoparticles dispersed on 2D amorphous carbon nanosheets accomplished the optimal current density and the maximum durability with the minimum decline during the entire test, sustaining 93% activity after 20000 s [161]. Wang and co-workers [162] reported an efficient ORR catalysts containing Pd hydride nanocubes encapsulated within 2D amorphous Ni-B nanosheets. At 0.90 V versus RHE, the Pd mass activity of PdH0.706 @Ni-B 2D composites reaches 1.05 A mg−1, which is nearly five times as high as that of commercial Pt catalyst. The 2D amorphous Ni-B nanosheets provided more defects or vacancies serving as active sites to promote the ORR activity.
Amorphous nature is metastable, which may slowly transform into crystal during long time storage. Thus, whether the amorphous nature of 2D amorphous nanomaterials can be remained during the catalysis process (both photocatalysis and electrocatalysis) is concerned by researchers. Jooss and coworkers [163] in-situ study the O2 evolution from H2O when manganite perovskites were used as catalysts via in situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM), which demonstrated that the edge of the manganite perovskite would collapse owing to the recrystallization and subsequent amorphization during the O2 evolution with the amorphous region kept during the in-situ test. Furthermore, the
transformation from crystal to amorphous generated by catalysis can also be seen in some transition metal sulfides [97-98]. Thus we tend to believe that the reversible reaction during the catalysis seems to be a lattice distortion process, so that 2D amorphous nanomaterials can keep amorphous after either photocatalysis or electrocatalysis. However, whether the amorphous nature can convert to crystal at some specific stages during the catalysis is still unclear and direct in-situ observation of 2D amorphous catalysts is still lack. More efforts are needed to study the stability of 2D amorphous nanomaterials in the future.

sections.heading: 3.3 Energy storage
sections.text:
At present, there is no denying the fact that rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors are two types of most widely investigated energy storage devices. Batteries are widely used in our daily life as a consequence of their low cost and rare environmental influence, although some disadvantages such as low energy density, short cycle life, slow charge rate, fire risk and so forth still trouble their application [164-165]. Supercapacitors are ideal energy storage devices due to their high power density, fast charge/discharge rate, long cycling life, low cost and safe operation conditions. Unfortunately, their energy density is relatively low compared to that of rechargeable batteries [166-167]. The performance of both batteries and supercapacitors highly depend on the properties of the electrode materials. Thus, exploring high performance electrode novel materials is an essential way to improve devices’ performance in energy storage, and lots of efforts have been made in developing novel electrode materials [168- 169]. 2D amorphous nanomaterials have feasible characters for batteries and supercapacitors such as extensive active sites, large surface area and fast electrons transfer. As a result, when the 2D amorphous nanomaterials are used as electrodes, the properties of batteries and supercapacitors will be sharply advanced.
Nowadays, Li-ion battery is the most widely commercially used rechargeable battery for portable electronics, and graphene was the first 2D nanomaterials used as anode for Liion battery [170], which exhibits a high capacity 744 mAh g1. 2D amorphous nanomaterials have been well studied and applied increasingly as the electrodes of batteries for the simple reason that amorphous nanomaterials can provide more active sites and faster electrons transfer than the corresponding one. Since first reported by Goodenough in 1997 [171], LiFePO4, has been commercially used as the cathode material of Li-ion batteries (LIB) because of its high theoretical capacity with high voltage, capacity retention under long charge/dis-charge cycling, safety, low toxicity, and low cost [172]. Besides, the graphene/2D amorphous Cr2O3 anodes certified strong adhesion to the current collector, which means they were still capable to be clung well on the current collector even after 5 minutes ultrasonic cleaning (Figure 12d). By contrast, under the identified circumstance, the graphene/crystal Cr2O3 anodes spalled (Figure 12d). Furthermore, the graphene/2D amorphous Cr2O3 nanosheets could not be peeled off by scotch tap while the crystal one was easily stripped off (Figure 12e). The larger contact area and more chemical bonds caused by more active sites contributed to the strong adhesion, promoting their energy storage performance. When comprising amorphous nanosheets with good conductive materials such as carbon and graphene, their energy storage ability for Li-ions can be further improved [100,173]. For instance, Li-ion battery with a graphene/M-CSO nanosheets as anodes shows ultrahigh reversible capacities of 1100 and 515 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at a high rate of 3 and 10 A g−1, respectively, so that the fast charge/discharge process was achieved [100]. Although Li-ion battery is promising power source for portable electronics, the lack of Li in the earth evidently increase the price of Li and restrict the improvement of Li-ion battery [174]. Thus, some fancy batteries based on earthabundance battery, such as Na-ion battery and K-ion battery have approached scientists’ horizons [169,175]. 2D amorphous FePO4 nanosheets were recently developed as an efficient cathode for Na-ion battery [110]. They displayed a high initial discharge capacity of 168.9 mA h g-1 at 0.1C, ultralong longevity (92.3% capacity retention over 1000 cycles), and high rate capability (77 mA h g-1 at 10 C) for Na-ion storage, which was superior to the crystal FePO4. Composites consisting of both crystal and amorphous phase may generate excellent energy storage performance as well. Alshareef and co-workers [176] deposited amorphous HfO2 thin films on MoS2 nanosheets, which displayed a specific capacity of 636 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles in Na-ion battery, while the bare MoS2 only showed 436 mAh g-1. Amorphous HfO2 thin layer acted as a passivation layer at the anode/electrolyte interface and blocked structural degradation during charge/discharge process. For supercapacitors, it is imperious to improve their energy density without sacrificing their power density. Surface area and electrical conductivity of the electrode materials greatly influence the performance of the supercapacitors [166]. Up till the present moment, there are two main charge-storage mechanisms for supercapacitors, one is based on the electric double-layer capacitor (EDLC) mechanism and the other is based on the faradaic redoxreaction to achieve pseudocapacitance [178-179]. It is viable for 2D structure to provide large surface area owing to their atomic thickness and large lateral size. Besides, with amorphous nature, more active sites for the charge storage become visible. As a result, the 2D amorphous nanomaterials exhibit remarkable energy storage performance used as electrodes in supercapacitors. For instance, 2D nickel-cobalt hydroxide (NiCo-LDH) nanosheets depositing on the surface of carbon fiber paper (CFP) have been demonstrated as promising electrode materials for supercapacitors to achieve high power density and high energy density [89]. The amorphous NiCo-LDH based supercapacitor revealed a high specific capacitance of 347 mF cm-3 or 1850 F g-1. Additionally, even at a high current density of 133.33 A g-1, they can still maintain 287 mF cm-3 and 1530 F g-1 respectively. The 2D amorphous structure provided deep electrolyte penetration for electrons and OH ions during the period of redox reaction, leading numerous sites spread over a wide variation in energies to achieve the ideal capacitor performance. Similarly, some other amorphous metal hydroxides with nanosheets morphology such as Ni(OH)2 [48], NiCo-OH [76] have also been demonstrated showing exceptional energy capacity when they are used as electrode in supercapacitor. Take the nanoflake array assembled from 2D amorphous cobalt–oxalate coordination polymer thin sheets [117] as another example. They unfolded excellent pseudocapacitive performance with a high specific capacitance of 702.75 F g-1 at 1 A g-1 and prominent cycling stability (94.3% of the capacitance at the 1000th cycles).
The stability of amorphous nature of 2D amorphous nanomaterials used as electrodes is important to understand their energy storage performance. As discussed in phase transformation synthetic method section, ions embed and disembed the lattice during the charge and discharge process in devices is an alternative way to promote the conversion from crystal to amorphous for various kinds of materials [95- 96,100]. Based on above, we hypothesize that the amorphous nature of 2D amorphous nanomaterials can be kept after charge and discharge as the ion plays an essential role of lattice distortion. Similar to the study of 2D amorphous serving as catalysts, lacking direct evidence such as in-situ TEM still restrict the development of a convincing conclusion
about the stability of amorphous nature. Besides, whether the 2D amorphous nanomaterials will convert to crystal when they are immersed in electrolyte and thermal influence during the charge and discharge is still unclear. More investigations are needed.

sections.heading: 3.4 Mechanics
sections.text:
Amorphous materials exhibit marvelous mechanical properties owing to their lack of grain boundaries and dislocation, which is commonly appeared in crystal. For instance, the amorphous CoTaB alloy achieved a world record compressive strength of metal up to 6 GPa [41]. Besides the mechanical homogeneity caused by the disordered structures and structural uniformity of amorphous alloy, rich boron (B) atoms in the amorphous alloy (35%) was another reason contributing to the world record compressive strength. Specifically, the B atoms could form local solute-centered coordination polyhedral with surrounding Co and Ta atoms, so that the intensive chemical short-range order caused by the strong covalent metal-metalloid bonds could sharply promote the strength and modulus of the amorphous alloy. Moreover, ultra-high modulus of Ta also further contributed to the improvement of their mechanical property [41]. Effectively, one of the most obvious characters of 2D nanomaterials is their excellent mechanical performance (e. g. graphene possess a high modulus of 1 TPa and fracture strength of 100 GPa [180]) owing to their strong in-plane covalent bond [3]. Thus, the strong in-plane covalent bond generated by 2D structure can further concentrate the chemical short-range order of 2D amorphous nanomaterials, which could dramatically improve their mechanical properties to satisfy the demand of structural applications.
Bulk amorphous alloy (metallic glass) has long been investigated as high mechanical performance structural materials [32]. Cutting them into the micro/nano scale, the bulk amorphous alloy reflect their predominantly improved mechanical properties. Ma and co-workers [181] synthesized CuZr amorphous alloy with belt-like (atomic thickness) morphology incised from the bulk amorphous CuZr alloy using mechanical cutting and focused ion beam (FIB) cutting. The belt-like amorphous CuZr nanoalloy showed a high tensile strength of 3.8 GPa, 2.3 times higher than that of bulk amorphous CuZr alloy (1.6 GPa). Besides, the amorphous alloy with atomic thickness displayed a large fracture strain of 5.3%, almost 3 times as high as that of bulk alloy (1.8%), indicating the excellent toughness of the amorphous one. The atomic thickness could strengthen the in-plane covalent bond, so higher mechanical performance was achieved and their structural application is extended. With regard to the excellent mechanical performance of 2D amorphous nanomaterials, it’s an alternative method for realizing ideal combination of strength and toughness to bring in 2D amorphous nanomaterials into composites as wild phase. Guo and co-workers [182] synthesized 2D amorphous Al2O3 (AA) nanosheets through simple wet-chemistry method. The layered film reinforced by amorphous nanosheets achieved the combination of high strength and high toughness, which endow them with great potential structural applications in fields of aerospace and manufacturing.

sections.heading: 3.5 Other applications

In fields of organic catalysis, 2D amorphous nanomaterials are widely applied as well. For instance, amorphous Fe nanosheets obtained by reducing a concentrated FeSO4 solution show a conversion more than 84% and a complete selectivity for cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone in the

Recently, Zhang and co-workers have demonstrated the dual-phase (amorphous/crystalline) Pd nanosheet is an effective catalyst for selective hydrogenation of 4-nitrostyrene. The crystallinity of dual-phase Pd nanosheets can be controlled. High percentage of amorphous phase of which exhibit an excellent chemo-selectivity (> 99%), while those with high percentage of crystalline phase show a higher catalytic activity (100%) [185].
In fields of biosensing, 2D amorphous nanomaterials are also up-and-coming. 2D amorphous MoO3 nanosheets were introduced into an optical biosensing system, where bovine serum albumin (BSA) was used as a model protein for assessing the sensitivity [99]. Actually. the magnitude of plasmon resonance relies on the concentration of BSA, which means that the amorphous MoO3 nanosheets can supply a platform to quantitative test of cell or organism. As a consequence, such systems could have a potential use for future sensing and optical operation with high precision. A ZnO nanocage assembled from 2D amorphous nanosheets displayed excellent performance in surface enhanced raman scattering (SERS) with ultrahigh SERS activity (EF up to 6.62×105), which can be used in bio-detecting and biosensing [186].
In fields of magnetizations, 2D amorphous nanomaterials also expose unique performance. The 2D amorphous NiCu nanosheets (Ni68Cu32) exhibited a magnetization of 0.20 emu g-1 and a coercivity of 42.70 Oe, indicating their super paramagnetism [131]. It should be noticed that, the magnetization properties of the 2D amorphous alloy can be tuned by controlling the content of Cu elements in the alloy.
To sum up, benefiting from the advantages of both 2D structure and amorphous nature, the 2D amorphous nanomaterials were widely used in fields of catalysis, energy storage and mechanics and exhibited excellent performance. The large surface area and numerous active sites generated by the 2D amorphous structure heavily accounted for their marvelous performance of catalysis and energy storage. Also, the ultra-strong in-plane covalent bond, atomic thickness and lack of dislocation promote their mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
Recently, with numerous efforts having been made in fields of 2D amorphous nanomaterials, outstanding progress have been achieved including both synthesis and applications. In this review, not only did us summarize the recent reported 2D amorphous nanomaterials, consisting of metal oxide, metal hydroxide, metal chalcogenides, alloy, silicates and carbonbased nanomaterials, but we also concentrated on the various synthetic methods and promising applications. The synthetic methods can be classified as top-down and down-up systems, most of which are modified from the well-studied 2D crystal
synthetic methods by introducing some blocking mechanisms such as insufficient energy, rapid reaction, competitive coordination/adsorption and lattice distortion to restrict the formation of crystal and stabilize the amorphous. Significantly, their unprecedent properties generated by the unique 2D amorphous structure are explored for various applications such as catalysis, energy storage and mechanics, most of which show better performance than the corresponding crystal one owing to more active sites and easy electrons transfer that the 2D amorphous nanomaterials possess.
However, every coin has two sides. Having throughout examined the progress of 2D amorphous nanomaterials, we draw a conclusion that they are not as clear as the crystal one, leaving us some unsolved problems and challenges. Firstly, the synthesis mechanisms for 2D amorphous nanomaterials are not well understand. Concretely speaking, the structure of amorphous nanomaterials are always considered as longrange atomic disorder and the growth of amorphous materials can not be directed by the intrinsic lattice direction. Hence, the reason why it is likely for them to grow to 2D structure is not well defined. Nevertheless, these mechanisms always make contribution to direction of the external factors such as hard/soft templates. Moreover, the synthesis mechanism explanation now is still the experimental phenomenology since rare critical fundamental theories have been proposed. At present, the synthesis of 2D amorphous nanomaterials is a hit-and-miss affair instead of planned research as the lack of theoretical direction. As a result, the number of successful synthesis for 2D amorphous nanomaterials are much smaller than that of the 2D crystal nanomaterials, which heavily restrict the development of 2D amorphous field and limit their applications. Thus, more conducive investigations focused on the intrinsic growth mechanism are in dire demand.
In addition, keeping stable is another challenge for 2D amorphous nanomaterials. For one thing, the 2D structure are easily destroyed by their high tendency to irreversible aggregation owing to their high surface energy and high tendency to chemical reaction owing to their high content of active sites during their application process, which greatly restrict their potential applications. For another, the amorphous nature is unstable at some degree, some of which tend to transform to crystal even during the storage, let alone the application. The introduced blocking mechanisms nowadays used for synthesis of amorphous materials can only decrease the tendency and rate to form crystal. That is to say they are not capable to completely interdict the transformation, so that the amorphous nature can be only reserved within a certain time. Therefore, it is of great importance to make 2D amorphous nanomaterials from both morphology and structure for their synthesis and application. More explorations of simple but reliable methods to stabilize these 2D amorphous nanomaterials are indeed necessary.

To expand their applications, the most straightforward idea is synthesize more kinds of 2D amorphous nanomaterials which manifest exhibit properties and functionalities. Another selectable way is to combine 2D amorphous nanomaterials with other functional materials, such as graphene/amorphous alumina nanosheets hybrids achieve exceptional combination of high strength and high toughness. The benefits from different constituent in composites can validly overcome each disadvantages and expand their function. Given that the unique structure and unprecedented properties of the 2D amorphous nanomaterials, it is rational to spare no effort to more make tremendous progress in synthesis and applications to better satisfy the need of fast-developing modern society.

metadata.abstractText: Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials (sheet-like materials with few-atoms thickness and lateral size above 100 nm) have always aroused scientists’ interests since 2004 when Novoselov et al successfully exfoliated graphene from graphite using Scotch tape. It is some unique characters of 2D nanomaterials such as the confinement of electrons in two dimensions in the ultrathin region, strong in-plane covalent bond and atomic thickness, ultra-high specific surface area and exposed atoms that enable 2D nanomaterials to show excellent properties in electrics, catalysis and mechanics. Recently, amorphous materials (varied from crystal materials by atomic arrangement) have demonstrated high performance in mechanics, catalysis and magnetic owing to their unique long-range atomic disorder arrangements. Thus, the 2D amorphous nanomaterials inspire a new path to the study of high performance 2D materials. Herein, we summarize the recent progress in 2D amorphous nanomaterials, whose synthetic methods and potential applications in fields of catalysis, energy storage and mechanics discussed in details. The vital blocking mechanisms for synthesis of 2D amorphous nanomaterials and their performance-structure relationship are focused on. Finally, we conclude the review with our personal insights and provide a critical outlook for the development of 2D amorphous nanomaterials.
